awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Study of Interactional, Organizational and Professional Mechanisms of Disadvantage in the Underrepresented and Marginalized STEM Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported the EHR Core Research (ECR) program.  ECR emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.  This research project is making contributions to the field in the areas of STEM workforce development and broadening participation in STEM.  The proposed work is advancing basic understanding about the intersectional mechanisms of disadvantage, at the interpersonal, organizational and professional levels, for underrepresented groups in STEM.  There is a pressing need to ensure that a diverse STEM workforce is engaged to advance our nation's progress in science, engineering and education, to address national societal needs through STEM research and education, and to contribute to the 21st century U.S. workforce.  By better understanding the professional, workplace and interactional variables that contribute to mechanisms of disadvantage, marginalization and underrepresentation of STEM professionals, our nation can better address barriers to success, can more strongly facilitate the integration of STEM education and research, and can enhance our engagement of a diverse 21st century workforce.  

Project leaders at Rice University and Temple University are collaborating to collect survey and interview data from STEM professionals about social and cultural variables found at the interpersonal, organizational and professional levels that produce disadvantage and marginalization in the workplace.  They are examining demographic variables, such as race, ethnicity, age, gender, sexuality, and disability, and the researchers are conducting numerous measures of workplace policies and practices, of interactional climates on the job, and of professional cultures.  The data is being used by the researchers to better understand the interactions among these data to advance knowledge about disadvantage for underrepresented STEM professionals in the U.S.  At the completion of this exploratory study, it is anticipated that results will inform future basic and applied broadening participation in STEM research about our nation's underrepresented STEM workforce. The results of this work are expected to be shared with education and STEM researchers in professional publications and shared with STEM professional organizations, employers and the public in study briefings.

Collaborative Research: A Study of Interactional, Organizational and Professional Mechanisms of Disadvantage in the Underrepresented and Marginalized STEM Workforce

The overarching goal of this project is to advance scholarly understanding of inclusion and marginalization processes in STEM (science, technology, engineering and math), especially for sexual and gender minorities. We examine mechanisms of disadvantage at interactional, organizational, and professional levels through the collection and analysis of unique survey and interview data of STEM professionals and to disseminate those findings to scholars and the broader public.

We surveyed members of 21 professional STEM societies in the United States, with a total of 25,324 interview participants, 1006 of which are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ). Interview participants (N=90) were primarily drawn from survey respondents who opted in. When possible, interviews were conducted in person with STEM professionals across the United States, maximizing diversity across race/ethnicity, gender, ability/disability, region, and STEM profession.  Interviews involved discussions of career history, dynamics in current workplace, and career aspirations. Combined with our pilot interviews (N=27), this produced a full sample of 117 interview respondents (25 lesbian, 39 gay men, 26 bisexual/pansexual/queer, 37 straight, with 19 transgender/gender non-conforming across sexual orientation categories). The sample includes 20 URM, 17 Mixed URM/non-URM, and 80 non-URM respondents. Additional interviews (N=8) were conducted with leaders of organizations promoting LGBTQ inclusion in STEM to provide further context and history.

Our first key finding based on survey data is that LGBTQ respondents report more marginalization, less professional respect, and less positive health and wellness outcomes compared to their heterosexual peers We find that LGBTQ respondents report more marginalization, less professional respect, and less positive health and wellness outcomes compared to their heterosexual peers in their organization. We find substantial differences by gender, race/ethnicity, and disability status: women, persons with disabilities, and some racial/ethnic minority group members are significantly more likely to report experiences of marginalization in their workplace than their colleagues.

Our second key finding based on interview and survey data is that the way that STEM work is organized has a significant impact on the workplace experiences of LGBTQ STEM professionals.  At workplaces where work is characterized by project-based short-term workgroups that are often reshuffled, LGBTQ STEM professionals must do more work to manage relationships with non-LGBTQ peers compared to those working in more long-term groups.

Analyses based on this data continue, including investigating the relationships between LGBTQ workplace experiences and the broader structure of gender in STEM, relationships between region and LGBTQ workplace climate, experiences of bisexual professionals relative to non-bisexual LGTQ peers, the impact of neoliberalism on LGBTQ inclusion efforts and navigation strategies, and effects on STEM training when coming out is a competing priority.

Intellectual Merit

This study is the first of its kind to examine experiences of LGBTQ STEM professionals using a representative nationwide sample.  Careful attention was paid throughout to attend to intersections of LGBTQ status with race/ethnicity, disability status, and gender to investigate the contours of marginalization within a broader intersectional matrix.    Interview respondents were selected with the intent to maximize diversity across sector, profession, region, and demographics.   The study has resulted in substantial contributions to literatures on LGBTQ inequality in STEM, including documenting systemic disadvantage for LGBTQ professionals in STEM with the first nationally representative sample, documenting mechanisms of disadvantage including work structure, and documenting with finer granularity ways that processes of LGBTQ disadvantage intersects with other systems of structural disadvantage.

Broader Impact

Findings from this study have been presented at numerous professional conferences, symposia, federal agencies, and university colloquia, and they have been published in highly profile professional journals Science Advances and Work and Occupations (see http://steminclusionstudy.com). These findings provide an important basis for advocacy on LGBTQ inclusion in STEM, firmly documenting that LGBTQ professionals are at a systemic disadvantage in STEM fields.  This research strongly supports efforts to encourage federal agencies and other organizations collecting data on the STEM workforce to include measures of sexual orientation and gender identity (SOGI) and to conduct analysis of comparable outcomes on this basis (LGBTQ vs. non-LGBTQ).

Findings from the full interview sample, along with discourse analysis of organization literature and news media, have been analyzed for a book manuscript, tentatively titled Out Doing Science: LGBTQ STEM Professionals and Inclusion in Neoliberal Times, co-authored by Tom Waidzunas, Ethan Levine, and Brandon Fairchild. The manuscript, currently under review at University of Massachusetts Press, examines the social history of LGBTQ inclusion efforts in the United States from the 1970s to the present. This manuscript is intended to raise awareness of successes and challenges for LGBTQ inclusion in STEM, examining ways that neoliberalism has both enabled and constrained these efforts.
